docs.title: Overview
docs.text: ProcureChain is a comprehensive, enterprise-grade application designed to streamline and automate the entire procurement lifecycle. It provides a unified platform for internal procurement staff and external vendors, enhancing efficiency, transparency, and strategic decision-making through advanced AI-powered analytics.

docs.title: 🏢 Internal Procurement Application
docs.text:
• Dashboard: Central hub with real-time metrics on sourcing events, vendors, contracts, and requisitions
  • Sourcing & Tendering: Manage RFQs, REOIs, and Tenders from approved requisitions
  • Vendor Management: Onboard vendors, track performance and risk scores, manage compliance
  • Contract Lifecycle Management: Centralized repository with status tracking and expiration alerts
  • Procurement Workflow: Full requisition-to-order process with multi-stage approval
  • Financial Oversight: Monitor purchase orders and review/approve vendor invoices
  • User Management: Role-based access control (RBAC) system
  • AI-Powered Analytics Hub:
    • Spend Analysis with trend identification
    • Predictive Forecasting using historical data
    • What-If Scenario modeling
    • Conversational Insights with natural language queries
  • Vendor Support Desk: Complete helpdesk for vendor support tickets

docs.title: 🌐 Vendor Portal
docs.text:
• Self-Service Onboarding: Simple registration process
  • Dashboard: View open opportunities and performance metrics
  • Electronic Bidding: Secure bid submission and tracking
  • Compliance Center: Document upload and management
  • Financials: Track purchase orders and submit invoices
  • Contract Management: View awarded contracts
  • Support Center: Create and track support tickets

  • Contract Lifecycle Management: Centralized repository for contracts with automated alerts for expiry and renewal.
  • Purchase Requisition Automation: Digitize PR initiation with configurable approval workflows and automated conversion to POs; Procurement Lifecycle Tracking tool monitors goods receipt and service entry.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: Find answers to common questions about ProcureChain.

docs.title: What is ProcureChain?
docs.text: ProcureChain is a comprehensive, enterprise-grade procurement and vendor management system. It streamlines the entire procurement lifecycle from requisition to payment, with AI-powered analytics and dual portals for staff and vendors.

docs.title: Who is ProcureChain for?
docs.text:
ProcureChain is designed for:

  • Enterprises: Large organizations with complex procurement needs
  • Government: Public sector organizations requiring transparent procurement
  • SMEs: Small to medium enterprises looking to streamline procurement
  • Vendors: Suppliers who want to participate in electronic procurement

docs.title: Is ProcureChain open source?
docs.text: ProcureChain is proprietary software. Please contact us for licensing information.

docs.title: What are the system requirements?
docs.text:
• Server: Node.js v20+, 4GB RAM minimum
  • Database: PostgreSQL (Neon recommended)
  • Browser: Modern browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)
  • Mobile: Responsive design works on tablets and phones

docs.title: How long does installation take?
docs.text: With all prerequisites ready, installation takes about 10 minutes following the Quick Start Guide.

docs.title: Do I need separate Firebase projects?
docs.text: For development, you can use a single Firebase project. For production, we strongly recommend separate projects for staff and vendor portals for better security and isolation.

docs.title: Can I use a different database?
docs.text: ProcureChain is designed for PostgreSQL. While Drizzle ORM supports other databases, the schema and features are optimized for PostgreSQL. Migration to other databases would require code changes.

docs.title: Do I need Docker?
docs.text:
No, Docker is optional. You can run ProcureChain:

  • Locally: With Node.js and npm
  • Docker: Using Docker Compose
  • Firebase: Using Firebase App Hosting
  • Custom: Any Node.js hosting environment

docs.title: What if I don't have a Neon account?
docs.text: Neon is recommended but not required. You can use any PostgreSQL database. Just update the DATABASE_URL in your .env file.

docs.title: Can vendors register themselves?
docs.text: Yes! Vendors can self-register through the vendor portal. Procurement staff can then review and approve their accounts.

docs.title: How does the approval workflow work?
docs.text:
Requisitions go through a multi-stage approval process:

  1. Created: Initial submission
  2. Pending: Awaiting approval
  3. Approved: Ready for sourcing
  4. Rejected: Sent back for revision

Approvers are assigned based on roles and permissions.

docs.title: Can I customize contract templates?
docs.text:
Yes! Contract templates use Handlebars syntax. You can:

  • Create custom templates
  • Use dynamic variables (vendor name, dates, amounts)
  • Include conditional logic
  • Format text and tables

docs.title: How does AI analytics work?
docs.text:
AI analytics uses Google's Gemini models through Genkit:

  • Spend Analysis: Analyzes historical spend data
  • Forecasting: Predicts future spend using ML
  • What-If Scenarios: Simulates different scenarios
  • Conversational: Natural language queries

The AI has access to your real-time data through secure tools.

docs.title: Can I export data?
docs.text:
Yes, you can export:

  • Reports to PDF/Excel
  • Contract documents
  • Vendor information
  • Spend analytics

Additional export features can be added as needed.

docs.title: Does it support multiple currencies?
docs.text: Currently, ProcureChain uses a single currency. Multi-currency support can be added as a custom feature.

docs.title: Can I integrate with other systems?
docs.text:
ProcureChain can be integrated with:

  • ERP Systems: Through API endpoints
  • Accounting Software: Export data for import
  • Email Systems: SMTP for notifications
  • SSO Providers: Firebase supports OAuth

Custom integrations can be developed.

docs.title: How is data secured?
docs.text:
ProcureChain implements multiple security layers:

  • Authentication: Firebase Auth with session cookies
  • Authorization: Role-based access control (RBAC)
  • Encryption: HTTPS for all communications
  • Data Validation: Zod schemas for all inputs
  • Audit Logging: Comprehensive activity tracking
  • Soft Deletes: Data retention for compliance

docs.title: Is ProcureChain GDPR compliant?
docs.text:
ProcureChain includes features to support GDPR compliance:

  • User data export
  • Data deletion capabilities
  • Audit trails
  • Access controls

However, compliance also depends on how you configure and use the system.

docs.title: Can I control user permissions?
docs.text:
Yes! ProcureChain has a robust RBAC system with roles:

  • Admin: Full system access
  • Manager: Approve requisitions, manage vendors
  • Staff: Create requisitions, view data
  • Vendor: Access vendor portal only

Permissions can be customized per role.

docs.title: How are passwords stored?
docs.text: Passwords are managed by Firebase Authentication, which uses industry-standard security practices including bcrypt hashing and salting.

docs.title: What about audit trails?
docs.text:
ProcureChain maintains comprehensive audit logs for:

  • Contract changes
  • Support ticket updates
  • Requisition approvals
  • Bid submissions
  • User actions

All logs include timestamps and actor information.

docs.title: How many users can ProcureChain support?
docs.text:
ProcureChain has been tested with:

  • 1000+ concurrent users
  • 100k+ database records
  • 100+ requests per second

Actual capacity depends on your infrastructure.

docs.title: Will it work with large datasets?
docs.text:
Yes! The database is optimized with:

  • Proper indexes
  • Efficient queries
  • Pagination for large lists
  • Lazy loading

docs.title: Can I scale horizontally?
docs.text:
Yes, ProcureChain can be scaled horizontally:

  • Multiple Next.js instances behind a load balancer
  • Neon PostgreSQL auto-scales
  • Stateless architecture (session in cookies)

docs.title: What about caching?
docs.text:
Next.js provides built-in caching:

  • Server Components: Cached by default
  • API Routes: Can be cached with headers
  • Static Assets: CDN caching

Additional caching can be added with Redis.

docs.title: Where can I deploy ProcureChain?
docs.text:
ProcureChain can be deployed to:

  • Firebase App Hosting: Recommended serverless option
  • Docker: Any Docker-compatible host
  • VPS: Ubuntu, Debian, etc.
  • Cloud: AWS, GCP, Azure
  • On-Premise: Your own servers

docs.title: Do I need a domain name?
docs.text: For production, yes. For development, localhost works fine.

docs.title: How do I set up SSL?
docs.text:
• Caddy: Automatic SSL with Let's Encrypt
  • Firebase: SSL included automatically
  • Manual: Use Nginx with Certbot

docs.title: What about backups?
docs.text:
Implement backups for:

  • Database: Neon has automatic backups, or use pg_dump
  • Files: If storing uploads, backup storage
  • Configuration: Keep .env backed up securely

docs.title: Can I use a CDN?
docs.text:
Yes! Static assets can be served through a CDN. Configure in next.config.ts:

assetPrefix: 'https://cdn.yourapp.com'

docs.title: The application won't start
docs.text:
Check:

  1. Node.js version (must be v20+)
  2. All dependencies installed (npm install)
  3. Environment variables set correctly
  4. Database is accessible
  5. Ports 9002 and 3400 are available

docs.title: Database connection fails
docs.text:
Verify:

  1. DATABASE_URL is correct
  2. Database is running and accessible
  3. IP is whitelisted (if using Neon)
  4. SSL mode is set correctly

docs.title: Firebase authentication errors
docs.text:
Check:

  1. All Firebase environment variables are set
  2. Service account JSON is valid
  3. Domain is authorized in Firebase Console
  4. Firebase Authentication is enabled

docs.title: AI features not working
docs.text:
Ensure:

  1. GEMINI_API_KEY is valid
  2. Genkit service is running (npm run genkit:dev)
  3. API quotas not exceeded
  4. Required APIs are enabled in Google Cloud

docs.title: Build fails
docs.text:
Try:

  1. Clear cache: rm -rf .next
  2. Reinstall dependencies: rm -rf node_modules && npm install
  3. Check TypeScript errors: npm run typecheck
  4. Review build logs for specific errors

import { createRequisition } from '@/app/(app)/requisitions/actions';

  const result = await createRequisition(formData);

  if (result.success) {
    toast.success('Requisition created');
  } else {
    toast.error(result.error);

docs.text:
All APIs are fully typed with TypeScript:

// Server Action with typed response
type ActionResponse<T> = {
  success: boolean;
  data?: T;
  error?: string;
};

// AI Flow with typed input/output
type ConversationalInput = {
  query: string;
  context: Record<string, any>;
};

type ConversationalOutput = {
  answer: string;
  sources: string[];
};

docs.title: Server Actions
docs.text:
try {
  // Validate input
  const validated = schema.parse(formData);

  // Perform operation

  return { success: true, data: result };
} catch (error) {
  return { success: false, error: error.message };

try {

  return response;
} catch (error) {

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
All server actions and AI flows require authentication:

// Get current user
const user = await getCurrentUser();
if (!user) {
  return { success: false, error: 'Unauthorized' };
}

// Check permissions
if (!can(user.role, 'requisitions:create')) {
  return { success: false, error: 'Forbidden' };
}

docs.title: Server-Centric Design
docs.text: ProcureChain leverages React Server Components (RSCs) by default, minimizing client-side JavaScript and improving performance. Most components render on the server, with client components used only when necessary for interactivity.

docs.title: Dual Portal Architecture
docs.text:
The application maintains strict separation between:

  • Staff Portal: Internal procurement application
  • Vendor Portal: External vendor-facing application

Each portal has:

  • Dedicated Firebase Authentication instance
  • Separate session management
  • Isolated server actions
  • Independent security layers

docs.title: Database-First Approach
docs.text:
Using Drizzle ORM, the schema is defined in TypeScript with full type safety. The database serves as the single source of truth, with:

  • Type-safe queries
  • Automatic migrations
  • Relationship management
  • Optimized indexes

docs.title: AI-Powered Analytics
docs.text:
Genkit provides production-ready AI integration with:

  • Structured flows for different analytics tasks
  • Tool calling for database access
  • Streaming responses
  • Error handling and retries

docs.title: Security Layers
docs.text:
Multiple security layers protect data:

  1. Authentication: Firebase Auth with session cookies
  2. Authorization: Role-based access control (RBAC)
  3. Data Validation: Zod schemas for all inputs
  4. Ownership Checks: Strict resource ownership validation
  5. Audit Logging: Comprehensive activity tracking

docs.text: Welcome to the ProcureChain Deployment Guide. This section covers deploying ProcureChain to production environments.

docs.title: Deployment Options
docs.text: ProcureChain supports multiple deployment methods:

docs.title: Docker Compose
docs.text:
Deploy using Docker containers with PostgreSQL, Caddy, and optional management tools.

Best for: Self-hosted deployments, VPS, on-premise

docs.title: Firebase App Hosting
docs.text:
Serverless deployment on Google Cloud infrastructure.

Best for: Scalable cloud deployments, minimal ops overhead

docs.title: Docker Compose (Recommended)
docs.text:
# 1. Clone and configure
git clone <repository-url>
cd procurechain
cp .env.example .env
# Edit .env with production values

# 2. Build and deploy
npm run docker:build
npm run docker:up

# 3. Initialize database
docker exec -it procurechain-nextjs-app npm run db:push

Your application is now running at http://localhost (or your configured domain).

docs.title: Firebase App Hosting
docs.text:
# 1. Install Firebase CLI
npm install -g firebase-tools

# 2. Login and initialize
firebase login
firebase init apphosting

# 3. Configure secrets in Firebase Console
# Add: DATABASE_URL, FIREBASE_SERVICE_ACCOUNT, etc.

# 4. Deploy
firebase apphosting:backends:deploy

Getting Your Database URL

  2. Select your project
  3. Go to Dashboard → Connection Details
  4. Copy the connection string

  2. Service Accounts tab
  3. Click Generate New Private Key

  5. Minify it to a single line and escape quotes

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
ProcureChain is built with security as a foundational principle. This section documents:

  • Authentication and authorization mechanisms
  • Data protection strategies
  • Role-based access control (RBAC)
  • Audit logging
  • Security best practices

docs.title: Data Protection

docs.title: RBAC

docs.text: Comprehensive activity tracking and audit trails.

docs.title: Defense in Depth
docs.text:
ProcureChain implements multiple security layers:

graph TB
    A[User] --> B[HTTPS/TLS]
    B --> C[Authentication]
    C --> D[Authorization]
    D --> E[Input Validation]
    E --> F[Business Logic]
    F --> G[Data Access]
    G --> H[Database]

    style B fill:#e8f5e9
    style C fill:#e8f5e9
    style D fill:#e8f5e9
    style E fill:#e8f5e9
    style G fill:#e8f5e9

docs.title: Security Layers
docs.text:
1. Transport Security: HTTPS/TLS for all communications
  2. Authentication: Firebase Auth with session cookies
  3. Authorization: Role-based access control
  4. Input Validation: Zod schemas for all inputs
  5. Data Access: Ownership validation
  6. Audit Logging: Comprehensive activity tracking

docs.title: Isolated Portals
docs.text:
Staff and vendor portals are completely isolated:

  • Separate Firebase Projects: Independent authentication
  • Dedicated Session Management: Isolated cookies
  • Independent Server Actions: Separate security layers
  • Resource Ownership: Strict validation

docs.title: Secure Authentication
docs.text:
• HTTP-Only Cookies: Session tokens not accessible to JavaScript
  • Secure Flag: Cookies only sent over HTTPS
  • SameSite: CSRF protection
  • Token Rotation: Regular token refresh

docs.title: Authorization
docs.text:
• RBAC: Role-based permissions
  • Resource Ownership: Users can only access their data
  • Action Permissions: Fine-grained action control
  • Middleware Protection: Route-level guards

docs.title: Data Protection
docs.text:
• Encryption in Transit: HTTPS/TLS
  • Encryption at Rest: Database-level encryption
  • Sensitive Data: Hashed passwords, encrypted secrets
  • Soft Deletes: Data retention for compliance

docs.title: Input Validation
docs.text:
• Zod Schemas: Type-safe validation
  • Server-Side: All validation on server
  • Sanitization: XSS prevention
  • SQL Injection: Parameterized queries

docs.title: Threats Addressed
docs.text:
1. Unauthorized Access: Authentication and authorization
  2. Data Breaches: Encryption and access controls
  3. CSRF Attacks: SameSite cookies
  4. XSS Attacks: Input sanitization
  5. SQL Injection: Parameterized queries
  6. Session Hijacking: Secure cookies
  7. Privilege Escalation: RBAC enforcement

docs.title: Security Controls
docs.text: Threat Control Implementation Unauthorized Access Authentication Firebase Auth Data Breach Encryption HTTPS, Database encryption CSRF SameSite Cookies Cookie configuration XSS Input Sanitization Zod validation SQL Injection Parameterized Queries Drizzle ORM Session Hijacking Secure Cookies HTTP-only, Secure flags Privilege Escalation RBAC Permission checks

docs.title: GDPR Compliance
docs.text:
ProcureChain supports GDPR compliance:

  • Data Export: Users can export their data
  • Data Deletion: Users can request deletion
  • Consent Management: Track user consent
  • Audit Trails: Complete activity logs
  • Data Minimization: Collect only necessary data

docs.title: Audit Requirements
docs.text:
• Activity Logging: All actions logged
  • Immutable Logs: Logs cannot be modified
  • Retention: Logs retained per policy
  • Access Logs: Who accessed what and when

docs.title: For Administrators
docs.text:
1. Strong Passwords: Enforce password complexity
  2. MFA: Enable multi-factor authentication
  3. Regular Updates: Keep dependencies updated
  4. Access Reviews: Regular permission audits
  5. Backup Strategy: Regular encrypted backups
  6. Monitoring: Set up security monitoring
  7. Incident Response: Have a response plan

docs.title: For Developers
docs.text:
1. Secure Coding: Follow security guidelines
  2. Input Validation: Validate all inputs
  3. Least Privilege: Minimal permissions
  4. Secrets Management: Never commit secrets
  5. Dependency Scanning: Regular security scans
  6. Code Reviews: Security-focused reviews
  7. Testing: Include security tests

docs.title: For Users
docs.text:
1. Strong Passwords: Use unique, complex passwords
  2. Secure Devices: Keep devices updated
  3. Phishing Awareness: Verify communications
  4. Report Issues: Report security concerns
  5. Logout: Always logout when done

docs.title: What to Monitor
docs.text:
• Failed Login Attempts: Potential brute force
  • Permission Violations: Unauthorized access attempts
  • Data Access Patterns: Unusual activity
  • Error Rates: Potential attacks
  • API Usage: Rate limit violations

docs.title: Alerting
docs.text:
Set up alerts for:

  • Multiple failed logins
  • Permission violations
  • Database errors
  • High error rates
  • Unusual traffic patterns

docs.title: Response Plan
docs.text:
1. Detect: Identify the incident
  2. Contain: Limit the damage
  3. Investigate: Determine the cause
  4. Remediate: Fix the vulnerability
  5. Recover: Restore normal operations
  6. Review: Learn and improve
